assets.description: At least, now it’s called by the proper name. The old one was labeled as a servo, but in reality it is an actuator.

summary: While verifying that I have the proper movement on the trim tabs and the stabiliators, I noticed the indicator on the Ray Allen actuator stopped at one extreme and no longer tracked. I opened the actuator up and a small tab that moved the potentiometer had broken. As I went to remove it to see if I could epoxy it back together, I broke one of the ears on the actuator rod. This told me that the unit had become brittle. I spent $600 and two hours removing, replacing and re-verifying the trim.
title: Gee, This Looks Familiar

assets.description: The flox worked like a champ. It now stops right at the perfect distance with 6° down deflection on the tabs.

I decided to bend the cotter pins around so that it couldn’t rotate. I know you should normally take the long one over the end of the shaft and leave the other one straight, making it easier for removal. However, I hope to never have to replace these and didn’t want them digging into the plastic shaft.
Note the flox buildup on the right using the  Scotchweld 460

summary: There is about 3 mm too much movement on the trim servo. There are limit switches inside the servo housing. I’ve decided to build up the limit switch tab so that it turns it off sooner. It may cause the last LED not to light, but I would rather not exceed the design limits aerodynamically.
title: Vertical Trim Servo

assets.description: It’s difficult to see you, but I wanted to document the jam nut on the fork.
In the middle of the picture is the AN4-7 with the added washer.

summary: Went through all the mechanicals and made sure everything was there and torqued properly. The trim link attachment to the bell crank called for an AN4-6A.  However, with the correct AN 960–416L, it was clamping down on the fork. I had to switch to AN4–7 and then added a standard AN960–416 on the head side to reduce the lateral movement.
title: Lockdown Everything

assets.description: Woo hoo!  On the money!
This will need to be limited to 4° but I am only checking to see that I can achieve that. The upper stop for the elevator has not been set yet and won’t be until the fuselage is done.
This was only supposed to make it to 27.6°. I need to raise the stop on the mass balance arm but I i’m still waiting for the new one to come in.
Almost perfect and acceptable where it is now. Should be 12°.
Should have been 9.2° but, again we’re talking .4°

title: Verification Of Tailplane Range Of Movement

assets.description: Fork end. I’m still tweaking the distance before setting the jam nut.
Painted link bar installed

summary: Was able to spray primer inside to make sure I didn’t have any invisible rest in the future. I riveted the sleeve that connects the fork.
title: Trim Tab “Tee” Link Rod

assets.description: Final opening. Obviously, there will be some microglass work to be done, but I will wait until finishing the fuselage.

summary: Cutting the excess fiberglass was a little harder than what I expected. It took a little more sanding and grinding to get the edges clean, but I eventually got there. It may not be the prettiest fiberglass work, but I know it will retain its strength now.
title: Trim T-bar Hole Fix Part 5

assets.description: Sanded openings after the initial fill with flox.

I don’t know if anyone has ever coined this phrase, but I haven’t heard it before… “Peel ply don’t lie.” It’s amazing that you can actually see through both sheets of fiberglass better with the peel ply on. It lets you know if you have the sheets properly saturated.
Fiberglass panels cut on a 30° bias

summary: After sanding the openings and getting them back to where they belonged, I verified all of the clearances and reflections of the elevator and the trim tabs. Silly me… I forgot to get photos to document, but will do whenever I finish this phase. I’ve cut eight pieces of bid on a 30° bias. I will sandwich each side with two layers on the inside and the outside.
title: Trim T-bar Hole Fix Part 4

assets.description: Just a few bumps to fill before laying the glass but should be able to do that in the same pass.
It wasn’t too far off after removing the tape and putting the T bar in. At about an hour of grinding to do with the Dremel rotary tool.

summary: I love it when things turn out better than expected. I thought I would have to come out and build up a little more material. It turns out I had it fairly close. I should be able to do the fiberglass and just a few small fillings of flox on the edge. Hope to get that laid today but need to go to the store and get some more sanding pads for my Dremel detail sander.
title: Trim T-bar Hole Fix Part 3

assets.description: First pass of flox using the duct tape backer.

summary: I gave it a lot of thought and figured that the strongest and most manageable way to fill the hole would be to make a flox sandwich. I put some tape on the inside and then took flox and pulled it up against the edges to fill. I didn’t want this to be unmanageable, so I stopped when I got close. I will have to go back again tomorrow and finish filling after it cures. When all of it cures, I will sand and add two plies of bid on the inside and outside.
title: Trim T-bar Hole Fix Part 2

assets.description: After adjusting the linkage, I still had a small amount of grinding to do but was finally able to achieve the correct full up deflection.
I now have it where in trim all the way up, the T-bar doesn’t stop movement.  However, the linkage is bottoming out at 11.7.
The good news is that there is still space for the mass balance weight to go down.
The green painters tape shows the portion that did not need to be removed at the bottom.  Most of the right side of the hole will be filled back in.

As of this photo, I can only rotate the elevators 10.5°. Need to get it to at least 12 for up. There’s more than enough for the bottom it currently will go six. this is with full down trim. I get to do the exercise all over with full up.

summary: I’ve encountered what I consider the first semi major mistake by the original builder. The holes for the trim tab T-bar were not in the right place or the right size. I’ve had to trim about an eighth of an inch material forward. It looks like the original hole on the right was cut and then it was realized it was incorrect. Too much material removed at the bottom. Not enough at the top. First, I’ll make the hole big enough and then I will fill it with some flox and cover with BID to give it its strength back.
title: Trim T-bar Hole Fix Part 1

assets.description: Notice my fancy counterweights on the mass balance arm. I’m waiting for the new, modified version of the mass balance arm to come in from the factory.
It may not be obvious in the photo, but the hole is off center about a millimeter toward the bottom of the image. This came in handy to perfectly align in the tabs.

It’s difficult to see in the image, but the portion of the tab that meets the elevators are aligned perfectly on both sides. However, there is approximately a 1/16 inch difference between the two tabs near the elevator. I chose to have them aligned on the outside since the elevator will disrupt any airflow around that.

summary: Do you ever wonder if what appears to be a mistake happens for a reason? When I was creating the bushings to go into the trim tab T-Bar, a couple of them were obviously drilled slightly off center. I thought I would hang onto them for an emergency… But it turns out they came in handy. Although I had checked previously, when I was attempting the final alignment, I could see that the left trim Tab was about a half a degree higher than the right. I took the two bushings that were slightly off-center and oriented them appropriately in the T-bar so that the left one would go down a little and the right one would go up. I was then able to adjust the overall length to create perfect alignment. I wasn’t sure how I was going to do it otherwise unless I bent the tube.  I still have some trimming to do on the fuselage. I am only able to raise the elevator 10.5° and need to make it to 12. Looks like I have my work cut out for tomorrow.
title: Tee Bar Alignment

assets.description: They fit very snuggly in the ends, but can still be removed.
Nylon bolt mounted on the XY table. Drilled the quarter inch hole first before doing anything else. Noticed the original plastic bushing setting just to the left of the nylon bolt.
After grinding and putting a small chamfer on the end.  It weighs 0.55 grams more than the original.
I used two nuts to keep it level while I’m grinding it.
The bolt head after grinding it down.

summary: I didn’t like the little black plastic bushing that came with the kit. One was already missing and the one I have falls out of the tube so easily that I am concerned I will lose it. I started to order some more, but then thought he would be better if I had a nylon bushing with an interference fit. I started to create one but then realized a 7/16th inch nylon bolt  would fit very well. It gave me the interference fit I wanted and I was able to grind off the head so that the flange was no thicker than the original.  I drilled the 1/4” hole down the middle before doing anything.
title: Trim Tube Bushings

assets.description: The excess epoxy that had to be removed.  Neither elevator would go all the way on until I removed it.
Primered bottom after closing up the modification
Borescope and 1.5” grinder used to remove the excess epoxy

summary: The conditions were right to be able to clean and get some primer on the repairs. However, I wanted to make sure that I could get them on the plane. There was some epoxy from the flox that did work its way in between the torque tube and the sleeve. I gently used a drill at very low speed to grind it out. It really broke away more than ground off.
title: Prime And Remove Excess Epoxy

assets.description: Right elevator after using some glazing compound and drilling the drain hole.
Left elevator after sanding, glazing, and drilling the drain hole.
Right elevator after first sanding.

summary: I surprised myself and found that I did a fairly decent job of spreading the micro. I think both of them turned out fairly well. Was able to sand them to what I think is smooth. I’ll have to wait to get some primer on it. It’s too cold outside to clean these the way that I like to before painting. I was also able to get both drain holes drilled. The good news was I could see the black resin from my pre-made fiberglass panels when I drilled the holes. They were a little difficult to drill through, which, in the words of Martha Stewart…”That’s a good thing.”
title: Sanding After Closing Up Skin

summary: You know… I probably shouldn’t feel this way but today I’ve begrudgingly applied the micro over the glass. This whole modification was unnecessary, but there was no way to know it unless I did the destructive opening. Just feels like I’ve lost two weeks for such a small thing.
title: First Coat Of Micro

assets.description: Finished layup with peel ply.
It’s difficult to tell, but the green foam is actually recessed into the hole. The black piece of fiberglass is just laying there awaiting the flox and epoxy.
Close up of the fiberglass plug that is flush with the rest of the panel.  The red lines are on the peel-ply- not the BID.

summary: I decided to cut some fiberglass panel I had into the shape of the openings. I felt these needed to be structural since the edge of the rib had been cut. I laid a bed of flox under the edge of the opening by cutting the foam at an angle.  I then laid the pieces in and floxed the edges.  I then laid two plies of BID with 30 degree offsets.
title: Final Layups For Right And Left

assets.description: Even though I have peel ply over the glass, I still didn’t want to take a chance of it trying to pop up as it came over the lip. I put a piece of kitchen wrap, and then my silicone baking sheet on top of it with a small can of paint to keep everything weighted down.

summary: My peel-ply came in yesterday.  I wish I had waited for the left one. It certainly makes it easier to know you have the glass properly saturated.  This one went a lot faster now having the experience from the left one.
title: Bottom Pocket Complete- Right

assets.description: Notice the ball bearing clearance on the left of the pin.  This will allow a safe, secure use of the pin
The drain hole will go in the middle of the pocket as opposed to through the horizontal section of the rib where it originally was drilled.
The transition from the torque tube actually turned out better than expected.

summary: So the pocket on the bottom side turned out better than expected on the inside. After opening up the PIP pinhole, which was a quarter inch, I took a 5/16 drillbit and cleared the fiberglass around that hole. That allows the pippin to go through unimpeded. I am also going to move the drain hole over to the center of the pocket as opposed to where it was originally drilled. The original spot was in the rib horizontal section. I am going to reinforce that from underneath and fill it. I will move the drain hole to outside the rib portion.
title: Bottom Pocket Complete - Left

summary: It was very tedious, getting the first piece of glass in through the hole. I had already laid up the flox on the edge just to give it a somewhat level playing field. After I had it stippled in place and was about to add the second piece, I remembered the technique that I saw in a dental video that I had edited. So I rolled the part that had to go the furthest back about an inch and then from the sides folded that in half. When I laid it in there and then unrolled it, it was perfectly placed. I stippled it in making sure no air bubbles. I thought I had some peel ply, but was mistaken. So I took kitchen wrap and laid it on the fiberglass and taped it into place so that there were no wrinkles. Then took a silicone baking mat and sat on top of that with a small can of paint for weight. That should turn out just fine.
title: First Layup - Left Side

assets.description: Nylon sleeve is used instead of hanging the elevators upside down on the plane
Foam “ramp” to angle the finished fiberglass supports.

summary:
I purchased a nylon Dowel. It was supposed to be 1 1/2 inches. It ended up being 1.6. I took it to a local machine shop and they turned it down to 1.495 inches. I’m using that on the inside instead of hanging it upside down on the actual steel pipe. I’ve also treated the nylon with a silicone release agent.
If there is going to be any purpose of this, I have to do it slightly differently. I fashioned a foam piece to fit over the nylon bushing so that if this ever is used to prevent separation from the airplane. I had to build a ramp. Otherwise, I feel that if I had the fiberglass close to 90° angle that it simply wouldn’t support it. I also will be attaching to the flox that is already around 75% of the sleeve.
title: Nylon Dowel

assets.description: Note the flox is up against the pin hole and was drilled to accommodate the pin.  I will attach my reinforcement to the flox.

I trimmed from the existing drain hole outward. I used the stud finder to see that the rib was further away. However, the fiberglass is thicker closer to the rib so I didn’t wanna cut any more than I had to.

summary: I am not real thrilled about doing this mod. I believe these were more than strong enough in their original form. If anything, I feel like I have weakened the rib. I will have to build it back up underneath. There is very little sleeve available to attach fiberglass too. I will shape some foam and build a little ramp to transfer any loads to the outer skin. Again, I don’t see how what was already there could possibly fail and that what I am adding would make a difference.
title: Opening The Skin – Left Stabilizer.

assets.description: End of the tube exposed.  I thought the tube was cut irregularly but it was actually flox from the original installation.

summary: I did the initial opening of the skin on the bottom side. Now that I can see the outside of the sleeve, I’m probably not going to do the modification exactly as described but I think it will be stronger. It appears that flox has been added to the bottom side and attached to the rib. This appears to be very, very strong. I do not want to disturb it. I will add the fiberglass to the inboard side and make it an angle and attach it to the skin. That will be a back up, but I don’t think it was necessary.
title: Opening The Skin - Right Stabilizer

summary: Used a 7/32” chainsaw file to elongate the holes for the pip pins
title: Torque Tube Elongations

assets.description: A stud finder can see the rib placement close enough to allow me te gently start the cut
Ear endoscope used to verify that the reenforcement had not been added and that there was foam all the way down.

summary:
I was going back through all of the mandatory modifications and realized this one had not been completed.
I used a little ear endoscope tool to look and verify that the foam was still on the lower side.
title: Mandatory Modification

assets.description: Both flaps with “adequate “ primer

summary: As we used to say in the edit bay… It’s better than good… It’s done. I struggled with the paint gun spraying consistently but was able to get it all covered.  I just want all parts that could be primed to have the first coat before heading to the paint booth.
title: Actual First Complete Coat Of Primer

assets.description: Tops turned out OK
Leading edge where the peel ply was not used and where there were joints is just so rough. Hopefully. This will be the last filling.

summary: I was able to spray the tops and bottoms of both flaps. At first, I thought I had a ton more work to do, but it looks like the tops are OK. Just a light sanding and another coat of primer should take care of everything. Still have some work to do on the bottoms though. The leading edge on both of them was just so rough. Probably a little more fill and sanding.
title: First Coat Of Primer

assets.description: The lighter colored areas are the low spots.  I could probably let most of it pass and fix it after the first primer coat, but I can feel a few of them. Will definitely fix those.
Guide coat showing lots of imperfections.

summary: I applied a guide coat this morning and let it dry. Was able to sand it down in the driveway. I suppose I shouldn’t be disappointed, but was hoping for a little better result. Need to level out the area around the rib and also do some filling and more feathering on the trailing edge.
title: Top Guide Coat

assets.description: Note the feathering from the right to the left.  I used a 6” putty knife but it only ended up leaving dry micro for the bottom 4 inches or so.  It was a very light skim to feather.

summary: I was able to sand both sides and come back with a coat of fairly dry micro. I built up and feathered out the valley angle on the bottom. I also had some pitting in the area where the peel ply had not been used.  I will need to follow up with a light sanding to knock the tops off and fill the pits with a slurry.  Should be ready for primer after that.
title: Leveling The Valley

assets.description: Tried to keep the dry micro to a minimum.  Very thin coat to fill the final “roughness” of the peel ply bumps.

summary: I think putting on two slurry coats first has helped a lot. I was able to put the dry micro on without getting it thick in very many places. I’ll do the bottom tomorrow and then sanding will tell.
title: First Dry Micro Coat

assets.description: Can still see some of the peel ply bumps but I would rather apply two coats of slurry for protection.  It’s a bit of a dance with making it too thick to fill the voids easily and having it settle too low because of being too thin.

summary: Spread the first slurry code on the top. It didn’t seem too rough. I like to get it kind of tight on the first coat. I have found that if I try to build it above all of the bumps from the peel ply that I end up with high and low spots. It ends up saving me time to wait and do a second slurry coat after I’ve sanded because it doesn’t become thick.
title: First Slurry Coat-Top

assets.description: Mixing cup with the chopstick.  The tip is able to efficiently fit in the bottom rim of the cup so that the epoxy is mixed well.  Popsicle sticks seem to be too thick or too thin depending on the angle.  The chopstick end is basically round and you don’t have to pay attention to the angle.

summary: I find that using chopsticks to stir the epoxy is easier for me than the popsicle sticks that come with a lot of kits. For me it’s easier to get in the corners of the cup and it just feels more natural in my hand. Plus they’re cheap. You can get a package of 100 sets (200 sticks) for $7 on Amazon.
title: Stirring Epoxy

assets.description: Area where peel ply had not been applied.

summary: There was an area near the leading edge where no peel ply had been used. I actually did not coat it yesterday afternoon so that I could smooth the leading edge. This morning, I was able to use the coat from yesterday as a level guide between the leading edge and the flat area. Hopefully, the 73° that I can maintain in the garage will allow this to cure enough to get the coat on the top this evening.
title: Second Slurry Coat -Bottom

assets.description: First slurry coat on the bottom.
The valley with its initial fill of dry micro.

Leading edge that has been smoothed with the painters tape. I took the non-sticky side of the tape and held it like you would a draw knife.  Then, I partially wrapped it around the leading edge and pulled it to me with less pressure on the leading edge.  This smoothed the micro so that I didn’t have bumps.
There is a small notch on each end. At first, I thought it was a chip, but these look purposeful. Need to go back through the documentation because I don’t remember anything about this.

summary: Now that I’m nearing the end of the fiberglass work, I’m getting a little more efficient- I think… I laid down the slurry coat on the bottom side, and then, with the leftover slurry, added some more micro to make my dry micro. I filled the valley at the trailing edge. I also took a paintbrush and painted the slurry on the leading edge. I then took a piece of painters tape and followed the curve and knocked down the high points. Hopefully, this will save me a lot of time.
title: Slurry Coat And Valley Fill

summary: This piece has been particularly challenging. The leading edge was just much rougher than I first thought. While nothing was over a millimeter off, it still had a lot of bumps and holes. I think I have 99% of them. Priming will tell.
title: Touch Up Before Priming

assets.description: All the little red circles are where I needed to fill

summary: Upon close inspection with a bar light, numerous pinholes were detected. Going to mix up some slurry just slightly drier than regular slurry and fill these areas. I didn’t see anything else but a few minor scratches that the Stewart Systems EkoPrime should be able to take care of.
title: The Dreaded Pinholes

assets.description: After first primer cost
Area that needs a little fill

summary: Let’s call the first coat where you hope that you’ve got everything close to being right as the “verification” coat. I expected to have 20 or more minor fills/repairs. I was unexpectedly and very, very pleasantly surprised to see that I only have one area on the top side that needs filling. Woo hoo!
title: “Verification” Coat

assets.description: Overall, looking better than expected
Leading edge still needs some work.
Need to sand and fill with some micro

summary: It was too cold outside – 36°F – to paint so I broke down and got a foam roller. I do have a bit of orange peel on the first part where I had too much primer on the roller. It’s certainly good enough to sand and see what I need to see. Once again, it turned out better than expected with only a few rough parts at the moment, but it hasn’t dried completely…
title: Top Side Primer Guide Coat

assets.description: A very light coat of the Stuart systems EkoPrime. Just enough so that I can see what I need to fix. That is the essence of a guide coat.

summary: This actually turned out better than expected. While it might look a little rough, it was expected to have some rough areas. I should be able to sand, glaze and then actually apply the first primer coat tomorrow. However, I may put the guide code on the other side in the morning and do all of the glazing and sanding at once. Tomorrow will tell.😜
title: Bottom First Guide Coat Of Primer

assets.description: Pits filled with dry micro
The green areas are where the high spots were. I filled on both sides.

summary: I was able to sand and then I actually had the micro a little drier than what I had first intended, but it worked out OK. I spread it first with a 2 inch steel putty knife and made it look like what I thought it should and then went back over it with the six inch  knife to take off the high spots. Also on the top side, there were some humps on the rib. I thought they were pretty bad, but after spreading the micro twice thinking I had messed up the first time It was actually pretty thin – I think… We’ll see tomorrow.
title: Filling Pits And Getting Over The Hump

assets.description: Closeup of one of the roughest areas that need filling.
Feathered edge after sanding.

summary: It actually turned out better than expected. The edge was pretty easy to feather. Now – and I hope I don’t regret this – I think I’m going to hit it with a slurry to fill in all of the pits from the dry micro. There could be some difficult sanding ahead for me…
title: Sanding Dry Micro Over “The Valley”

assets.description: After spreading the dry, micro and removing the tape.
Masking tape prior to laying the micro. Going to try and keep the knife edge right on the edge of the tape. Hopefully, we’ll come out flat without a bunch of holes.

summary: I thought I would tape off the section to ensure I wasn’t getting any thicker than I needed. I applied the dry micro with a 6 inch putty knife with one edge resting on the tape and the other over the trailing edge. I don’t think any section is over 1 mm thick. It didn’t turn out as smooth as I had hoped, but about what I thought it would be. Hopefully, less sanding and no unnecessary weight.
title: First Dry Micro Over “The Valley “

assets.description: Top sanded and ready for cleaning before dry micro.
Bottom after sanding and cleaning.
Taped hinge to prevent accidental scratches while sanding

I believe I will build up just a millimeter or two of dry micro and taper toward the middle of the flap for three inches or so.  I tested the corner and you can see it will be razor thin at the trailing edge. I don’t think that will be very durable.

summary:
Sanded the second slurry coat. It’s probably a little smoother than anticipated, but I still see lots of work ahead. Struggling with deciding whether or not to do a light primer coat as a guide coat.
I don’t intend on sanding closely to the hinges, but I tape them up to avoid scratches. Scratches can be the very beginning of fatigue cracks.
title: Sanding Second Slurry Coat

summary: Mixed another batch of micro to try and finish filling out the bottom.
title: Second Slurry Coat

assets.description: Before filling
Closeup of filled trough.  I prefer to have buildup at the end.  By scraping the putty knife down, I get a buildup and a good bond.
Initial fill of dry micro

summary: Apparently, when this piece was laid up. The top skin actually extended below the bottom skin by about a millimeter or two. I trimmed the trailing edge to make sure there was at least 2 cm of joined top and bottom skin. I was paranoid that if I filled the trough that would add a lot of weight. However, it only took 29 g of dry micro to do the majority of the fill. I would guess having that turbulence would add much more drag than what I’m gonna lose with the added weight.
title: Trailing Edge Fill

assets.description: Sanded after first coat
Seem where there are bumps on the edge and it’s low in the middle.

summary: I found on previous applications of the slurry coat and then following up with the dry micro that I ended up spending a lot more time fixing things.  Getting the slurry coat smooth the first time is difficult with imperfections at seams and so forth. I believe it will save me time to actually do two slurry coats. I sand off all the high spots of the first coat and then any low spots where I can still feel the peel ply bumps get fixed. Hopefully, in the long run, it will save me time and make it better.
title: Sanded First Slurry Coat

summary: Sad to say this is one of my worst initial spreads of the micro. I’m amazed at how much 4°F temperature makes on the consistency. I had been spreading earlier this summer when the temperature was between 72 and 76. This morning, the temperature was down to 68 in the garage and it just did not want to cooperate. I see lots of sanding in my future.😳
title: Bottom Slurry Coat

summary: Applied the first slurry coat to the bottom.
title: Top Slurry Coat

assets.description: Checking alignment with string.
Outboard hinge
Ready for slurry coat after it dries.

summary: I got the flap down off the shelf, took it outside and cleaned it prepping for surface finishing. I set the sawhorses up with foam to support it. I also checked proper alignment on the hinge holes. The castle nut had already been installed so I checked proper assembly.
title: Initial Cleaning And Check For Correct Washout

summary: Spent a couple hours this afternoon, shaping the foam. I’ll also create a box to safely set them aside along with the weights so that I know where they are.
title: Shaped Foam For Mass Balance Arms

assets.description: The reason you only want to use a dollop of epoxy to temporarily hold something. Lots of tedious sanding.
Cutting the majority off with a knife.
After removing foam and sanding.

summary: As stated on the right aileron, the original documentation had the templates labeled incorrectly and they were printed at 87%. Not only were these the wrong size but they were damaged. Had to remove them.
title: Remove Old Foam For Mass Balance Weights

assets.description: Outboard template printed at 100%
Lead weight placed up against foam to check fit
Rough fit of foam against the aileron
Finished foam blocks for the right aileron . Saving them in a Ziploc out of harms way so that they don’t get dented before installation.

summary: I accidentally skipped a module… But, since I already had the stuff for the ailerons down off of the shelves I decided to move forward. This will be the first ones that I can’t do the fiberglass finishing on because I have to do some trimming once they’re attached to the wing. I found that the first person who was starting these used a template from the manual. There were two problems; the templates were mislabeled for the inboard and outboard in the original documentation, and I discovered that the PDF file was stored to print at 87% size. I increased the print size to 100% and I’ve started cutting new foam for the arms.
title: Creating Mass Balance Arms

assets.description: Top view to see all 8 nuts.
My fancy tool for holding the bolt head inside the torque tube made from a PVC pipe
Just a small amount of flexing in the direction of the misalignment would make the binding go away
Torque-vue paint applied.
Image on borescope shows what it looks like from the inside.
You can see the thread that had been ground off to be able to make the turn.
All eight clamps installed but still need torque-vue paint to show if they have loosened.

I cut slots in the end so that I could slide the box end of the wrench into the pipe. I used duct tape to clamp it down so that I would be able to pull it out of the tube without it falling out of the pipe. The offset from center actually worked very well for keeping it up against the outside of the tube and being able to easily locate the bolt head.

summary:
I hit a snag… When I tightened the first clamp on the right stabilizer sleeve, the whole mechanism started binding again.  At first, I thought the clamp was causing the outer sleeve to form in an oval shape. However, with both clamps in and only finger tight, the binding was still there. It turns out the right brass bushing was very slightly misaligned. To confirm, I literally only had to take my left hand and slightly twist the fuselage near the shaft to make it unbind. I put a 0.001 shim under the right sleeve on the front to cant it very slightly. This reduced the resistance to almost nothing. This slowed me down for several days waiting for the shim to come in and to take care of some family stuff. I was sweating bullets to see the final outcome of getting all eight clamps in position and torqued down. I was very relieved to see that there was virtually no binding when I got all the clamps in.
I used an inexpensive borescope and a parts grabber to install the bolts from the inside. Once I figured out the technique, it wasn’t really all that bad but, yes, it was tedious. I also had to grind one thread down on the end of the 1 inch bolt to get the second screw at each point to make the turn through the hole. A three-quarter inch bolt went through very easily, but only left me with about one and a half to 2 threads when torqued down. I needed most of the 1 inch bolt to have enough to make sure I could torque it down and have clean threads.  Each of the saddle washers had to be fit for its specific location to allow clearance for welds and rounded corners to fit inside the nylon sleeves. all were installed with Loctite Blue 243 and torqued to 9 ft-lb except the front right stabilzer.  It caused a distortion of the tube and caused binding.  It was torqued to 6 ft-lb.
title: Final Installation Of Clamps

assets.description: Sleeve with Sharpie ink to show where there was excess contact.
Silicone lubricant that I used.
The other side of the sleeve showing the excess contact.
The ring all the way around did not bother me.  That small amount would wear away under normal break-in but I did a very light polish to reduce wear debris getting in the oil.
This was the second time.  Although the photos don’t do justice, the area of excess contact is smaller.
Everything in position with pins but not clamped.  There was no binding at this point.

summary:
I used acetone and a lint free cloth to clean the brass bushings and also clean the outside of the bearing surface of the elevator flanges. I used 100% silicone that appears to be about an ISO 320 viscosity. It’s actually labeled treadmill lubricant but it’s still 100% silicone and the viscosity I want. I wanted to use this instead of grease so that I could put a little sponge reservoir on top of the nylon later to ensure there’s constant lubrication. It seems to be fitting with an appropriate amount of “snugness.” There is no play from side to side and no resistance to the rotation. Only a small amount of force was required to fit the saddle washers in the nylon sleeves.
Unfortunately, this is where I found the bushing out of alignment. I marked each sleeve with a sharpie and then reinstalled it. It showed me where it was rubbing. I was able to take a Dremel tool and just a polishing wheel to remove enough material to free it up. I doubt I took even 1000th of an inch. I literally just polished it to shiny twice.
title: Installation And Final Fit Check

assets.description: Using a 1/4” drill bit to mark the center of the 3/4” access holes.  I then removed the tube and drilled the holes using a 3/4” paddle bit.
Access holes.  These were coated with epoxy since I wasn’t quite sure if this was plywood or composite material.

summary:
Marking through the torque tube with a 1/4 inch drillbit. Four holes will need to be drilled through the bulkhead so that the nuts and bolts can be accessed once the fuselages together. A three-quarter inch hole will accommodate the socket. If you choose to do the modification this way instead of the single clamp method, be sure the tubes is level before marking the holes. Also, I’m going to coat the inside of the opening and lap it over to ensure a seal from moisture.

Although I don’t intend on ever having to touch these again, I’m still prepping so that they could be replaced, if necessary. My access panels will be from the port side of the plane.
title: Preparing For Torque Tube Lockdown

assets.description: Final polishing to make a uniform surface.
An almost finished saddle washer.  Some of the top needs tote ground off.
Final set of clamps.
One pair of the clamp (Saddle washer and 1/2 moon key) with a 17/64th hole in the center.

summary: Creating a saddle washer, and a, sort of, half-moon key to bolt from the inside of the torque tube for the elevators to clamp down the outer components to the tube.  I did most of the work with a Dremel cutoff disk and then did a final polish with the grinder.  (You can see the cutoff disk in the lower left corner of the press photo).  Grade 5 bolts were only used for test fit.  Grade 8 were used for installation.  I weighed all of the pieces and the total weight was 7.2 ounces.  That’s 1/2 the weight of the aluminum mod kit that can be purchases.
title: Making Washers For Lockdown

assets.description: Primed after repair and initial coarse trim.
Note the fiberglass is broken at the bottom of the photo

summary: I accidentally dropped the trim tab while fitting the next piece. It landed on the extended corner where it had not yet been trimmed. It actually broke the fiberglass and not the joint. Even though I have a repair to do, I now know this is more than strong enough.
title: Unwanted Testament To The Strength Of Flox

assets.description: The black piece of fiberglass was clamped to the trim tab.  I then took a Dremel tool and cut small slots in both pieces.  I then filled them with flox.  After that cured, I laid two pieces of bid on the bottom.  The excess will be cut off and trimmed for final fit.

summary: For some reason, the trim tab for the left stabilizer was about a quarter of an inch shorter than the right trim Tab. I have looked at several examples and everyone else has them equidistant from the fuselage. Unfortunately, there isn’t enough excess to sand the right one down enough to match so I extended the Tab since it was such a small amount, I did not want to do a layup to build up extra weight. I took a Dremel tool and cut several small slots that did not penetrate all the way through. I then had matching slots on the piece of premade panel and filled them with flox. Looks like Frankenstein‘s monster… I added 3/8” and will trim.
title: Trim Tab Extension

assets.description: Small area of excess epoxy near the edge.
Note imperfections in the fiberglass where the top turns down.  These have been sanded smooth and the second coat of primer should cover them.

summary: Finished sanding and repairing most of the blemishes… The attempt was to get them all… But I knew there would be a few. It turned out well. I used a Wagner power painter with the stain nozzle and it worked out very well. Not a very large pattern, but it was quite atomized and made a smooth finish. Only three blemish areas on the top side.
title: First Permanent Coat Of Primer

assets.description: Only a small amount micro was needed to make the circle round.
Note the tie wrap in the cup.  It goes through the drain hole to stay secure while the micro is pushed in.

summary: The opening for the hole to access the pin to attach the stabilizer wasn’t very round. Also, I don’t know if I have the covers from the factory and cannot find images of one. I’ve decided to make a perfectly round hole and then I will actually use a piece of carbon fiber to cut a circle that will fill the hole and be able to seal below it. I will utilize a bar below it so that I can take a screwdriver and tighten it. wish me luck that the plastic cup with a bit of release agent on it actually comes out.😅
title: Pin Hole Opening/Cover

assets.description: Small nut and bolt installed so that I could remove the cap once the sealer cured.  Also used Teflon tape around the edges so that the sealer did not stick to the cap and offer a little bit pf clearance once everything is cured and the tape removed.
Countersinked center hole to be able to use a recessed retainer screw.
Using a bolt through the center of the rough cut carbon fiber.  Using a drill, I held it to the side of a bench grinder to make a perfect circle and periodically checked diameter.
It was easier to use a syringe to apply the small amount of 3M 4200
Sealer used for the seat
Cap seated into the 3M sealer.
Teflon tape application
Finished hole.

summary: After removing my cup, and having a perfect circle, I drilled some holes in some carbon fiber that I had and rounded them to match the cup. I used a drill and a grinder to grind them down . I then wrap the edges with Teflon tape so that I could set the cap into the 3M sealer that would create its seat. I let that cure overnight.
title: Seat And Cap For Pin Cover

assets.description: The guide coat showed a lot of imperfections with the dry micro application after sanding.
I used a green Sharpie to mark where the low spots were.  I then filled with dry micro.

summary: Sanded down the slurry coat from yesterday. Things worked out actually better than expected, but still another fill coat was needed. The top side will be ready for priming after the sanding.
title: Final Sand And Fill Before Primer-Top

assets.description: Second slurry coat.  First one did not come to the top of the peel-ply bumps.

summary: They underside seemed fairly smooth. There was still quite a bit of bumps that I could feel from the peel ply. I decided to do a second slurry coat before trying to fill any of the low spots. Plus, I sanded the top side, which took about an hour and a half. The bottom half required two separate batches of slurry to get smooth and everything covered.
title: Underside Second Slurry Coat

assets.description: The guide coat proves I stink at fiberglass work.

summary: Sanded the first coat of dry micro. I tried a different technique to spread it thinly but smoothly. Obviously, I did not succeed. You can see after sanding that there are many, many low spots. I knew there would be some problems on the edge where I ran out of micro, but wanted to get this coat sanded before adding more. The dark spots are from the guide coat.
title: When You Think You’re Spreading Smoothly…

assets.description: Initial coat of dry micro

summary: Covered the stabilizer on both sides with the slurry coat and have now started with the dry micro on the top. I will be trying a new method, literally using an icing knife for the first dry micro on the back. I forgot to use it this morning when doing the initial coat on the top.
title: Slurry Coat And Initial Dry Micro

summary: I went to Chattanooga to see Matt Cole‘s EuropaXS. The trip was both inspirational and educational. Matt has a nice plane set up very similar to what I am going to do. It was very valuable for me to see the finished product and some of the parts connected to each other.
title: Visit

assets.description: Clamps keeping everything aligned while the flox cures.
Note the cut in the brown fiberglass.

summary: It looks like John started trimming the root portion of the right horizontal stabilizer. However, it looks like he realized he was about 1/4 inch off from the leading edge and was going to be 1/8 inch off in the opposite direction at the trailing edge. He did not break the fiberglass completely at the end, but there was a gap. I filled the gap with flox and clamped it. I will add strips of bid after that cures.
title: Repaired Incorrect Trim

assets.description: The “0” and the “1/8” is where I needed to trim a straight line.  I needed to trim 1/8” off and reduce down to nothing once I got to the 0 mark.
Showing the desired clearance near the back of the stabilizer.
Trying to maintain 1/8” clearance for the entire length of the stabilizer.
Both Horizontal Stabilizers installed.

summary:
Quite a bit of polishing and aligning on both horizontal stabilizers to attach them to the torque tube. The torque tube has to be slightly reworked. There is a modification to clamp the components rather than rely on pins. The pins have a tendency to wallow out and develop some play.
There is a cut on the right stabilizer that now has to be reinforced. Apparently there was a mismeasurement and someone started trimming before fitting properly. I will lay up some bid underneath to reinforce as well as fill the void from the sawblade with with flox.
title: Initial Fitting Of Both Horizontal Stabs

assets.description: Guide coat shows low spots on the far end and in the middle.

summary: Not too bad.  I got it fairly flat.  You can see through the dry micro except in the low spots revealed by the guide coat.
title: Final Sanding-right Trim Tab

assets.description: Clothes pins holding the flattener strips in place.

summary: Added the Flettner strips this morning.  The plastic clothes pins seem to clamp at just the right angle to hold both sides flush with the trailing edge.  Hopefully, none of the plastic clothes pins will stick to the epoxy.  They didn’t on the left one.  I used low density PVC for the Strips.  This is the stuff you get at Home Depot for door trim.  It’s extruded which makes it consistent in dimensions and very light weight.  I tried to cut some aircraft grade spruce but it was too inconsistent with the dimensions. When you are only going from 3 mm down to zero in less than a 10 mm span, keeping within tolerance is difficult with non-perfect wood.
title: Flettner Strips

summary: Nothing like a guide coat of primer to show you exactly how uneven the surfaces are. It’s actually pretty flat. We’re only talking a thin film of paint difference.
title: Trim Tab Fill Sand

assets.description: Top side of the left stabilizer.

summary: I was able to sand both sides down to what I believe to be a level adequate for a finish. I found that wet sanding with 220 in a very light touch took off adequate amounts. I then followed up with 400 to give it a smooth finish. It did expose some of the micro filler that I had put on. However, (and you might think I’m crazy… ) but I am going to put the first coat of white paint on utilizing Krylon Fusion.  It does not require a primer. This way, I will be able to see progress and not have to stress the hinges if I decided to paint it after it was assembled.  I will decide later if I am going to use a two-part polyurethane for the second coat of white. I will definitely use a two part polyurethane clear topcoat to protect whatever I put on there.
title: Final Sanding

assets.description: Wet sanding keeps the dust down in the garage.

summary:
Primed this morning and then sanded this afternoon. Sandpaper kept clogging.  Switched to wet sanding which seems to work well.  Spent a good portion on the end of the stabilizer trying to figure out if it was a smooth hump or a reflection.
I have to admit, it’s a little disappointing to think you have got it smooth enough for primer and then when you sand the primer you realize how bumpy it was… I figured I would have a few few areas to touch up, but I’m only a fourth of the way through .
title: More Sanding

assets.description: Flap laying on foam blocks attached to the saw horses.  The blower is on a stool so that it blows the sanding dust into the yard.

summary: When life gives you lemons…  My wife decided she did not like the idea of me sanding in the garage even though the Eastwood system was excellent and capturing all of the dust.  I found that going out to the driveway, setting the work piece on saw horses with a foam mount to stabilize the piece and using a blower sitting on a stool next to the piece made it very efficient.  The blower would blow off any dust into the yard and I didn’t even have to wear a mask.  The dust doesn’t build up under the sandpaper increasing efficiency.
title: Sanding

summary: Verification of all of the layups and proper hole positions. There was a defect or dent in the TP5 sleeve in the 2 o'clock position abut 2.5 inches in. While only about 2/1000, it was enough to cause the TP4 tube to bind when trying to insert. The defect was a small pocket of a crystalline type substance... maybe a pieced of embedded sand. It was scratching the tube. It took several attempts to dig it out with dental picks and some light sanding and polishing.
title: Left Stabilator Layups and alignment

assets.description: Using an aerosol as a guide coat primer.  Will use Stewart systems for actual primer once it’s all sanded.
The entire trailing edge is low and will need a bit of dry micro.
Still low on the trailing edge on this side. Will need to fill more.

summary: The rudder is the first project. Since the original layup work was completed, I disassembled the rudder horn, treated it with clear coat to prevent rust. I have since decided I will paint it and all ferrous pieces a flat gray. While the layups looked good before attempting to primer, it turns out there were several low spots that had to be built up with micro. This was a bit tedious but it was a good confidence builder. I was probably being way too cautious with the sanding when I started but found several methods to accelerate the process. I still have a small amount of low spots to fill but will wait until I have started the next surface since I would have to mix a whole batch for what will probably be less than a tablespoon of filler needed. The $250 allocated to this included the cost of the sandpaper, sanding blocks and a handy system from Eastwood that allows me to sand in the garage without any dust. It attaches to the vacuum cleaner and collects the dust through holes in the sandpaper. (The following was added 11/5/25)  I had been documenting using the free EAA builders log but it was just too cumbersome.  I switched to KitFlight and it’s piece of cake using my phone to take photos and add captions as well as work completed. Much, much easier.
title: Rudder Work

assets.description: I didn’t want to drill and I will need to remove the black safety strap when attaching to the bottom half, so I used suction cup hooks.  I scuffed them up with sandpaper and used some JB Weld to attach to the fuselage.  I can raise and lower without interference.  Just hope sanding off the JB Weld won’t be too difficult.
Cradle to hold bottom of fuselage.  Will probably need to raise this 10” to get clearance
Brace made from scrap wood to support the front half of the fuselage from the ceiling hoist.
Used a kayak hoist to suspend top half of the fuselage until needed.

summary: I spent the first month after picking up the kit setting the shop up for success. The cradle is made from 2x4 and 2x6 lumber with casters from Amazon. The casters have locking brakes. The top half of the fuselage is suspended from the ceiling with a kayak lift system. Scrap from the cradle was used to build a support for the front half and four suction cups were epoxied on the rear to support the tail. There are safety straps in the event of a failure of one of the cups. This will allow it to not only be out of the way but also make it much easier during the fitting/trimming process.
title: Shop Set Up
